November 13, 2019 at 1:17 PM ¬∑

This week in Centers, we're answering questions with the words "YES" and "NO." Many children with language delays have trouble with these words and may do things such as restate an item instead of saying "Yes" (e.g., "Do you want juice?" "Juice!") or ignoring/pushing away something rather than saying "no."

You can help your child use these words verbally by pairing them with a hand sign when you say them. In addition to nodding your head for "yes," make a fist and "nod" it as well. In addition to shaking your head for "no," use the first two fingers of your right hand to tap your thumb.

If you ask your child a yes/no question and they reply with anything other than yes/no, you should also model the expected response when you repeat their answer.
E.g. --Do you want Juice?
-- Juice!
-- Yes, you want juice!

post_text: Valuing Our Children is now offering the Parent Child Home Program. This home visiting program is available to families with children ages 18 months to age three. The Home Visitor works with families twice a week for a half hour during the school year. They bring a brand now toy or book for the family to keep. During the visit, the home visitor models and encourages interaction between parent and child to strengthen the child's development and their school readiness. They have a few openings for families to start in mid September. Families can call Jen at VOC or they can email or message her through the Valuing Our Children Facebook page.
